passages.name: BEGIN
passages.text: <

passages.name: stand up
passages.text:
You scramble to your feet. The floor leaves splinters in your hands.

[[NOT HOME]]

passages.name: look around
passages.text:
You're lying on a rough wooden floor. The boards are warped and uneven, all splinters and crooked nails.

[[NOT HOME|nothome1]]

passages.name: welcome
passages.text: You've slept enough. [[A COLD HAND DRAGS YOU TO YOUR FEET|welcome 1]]

links.text: A COLD HAND DRAGS YOU TO YOUR FEET

passages.name: welcome 1
passages.text:
Look alive, kids. Say hello to your new friend. The shadows start to take shape, stirring from sleep, untangling themselves from ragged blankets on the floor. They're all around your age.
[[LOOK AT THE MAN]] [[LOOK AT THE CHILDREN]]

passages.name: title
passages.text:
<>\ <>\ <>\ <>\ <>\ <>\ \ b o g e y m a n\ \
BEGIN INFO
\ <><>[[BEGIN]]<><>\ <><>[[INFO]]<><>\ \ <><>b<><>\ <><>o<><>\ <><>g<><>\ <><>e<><>\ <><>y<><>\ <><>m<><>\ <><>a<><>\ <><>n<><>

passages.name: INFO
passages.text:
<<linkappend "CLICK HERE TO SEE CONTENT WARNINGS ''(SPOILERS)''" t8n>>
animal death (avoidable)
cannibalism
child abuse (physical + verbal)
child death
fire
kidnapping
sedation<</linkappend>>
Some common squicks, listed in alphabetical order. Except where marked, these are not easily avoided through the player's actions.

[[BACK|title]]

passages.name: LOOK AT THE MAN
passages.text: You turn, and are blocked by wall of black robes. From somewhere near the ceiling, a jagged mouth sneers down at you. Don't look so scared, little fish. This is your family now. [[ONE OF THE CHILDREN TAKES YOUR HAND|tabby]]

links.text: ONE OF THE CHILDREN TAKES YOUR HAND

passages.name: LOOK AT THE CHILDREN
passages.text:
They look sickly, but not starved. Their faces are creased with a kind of tiredness you've only ever seen in grown-ups before.

[[BEHIND YOU, THE MAN SPEAKS AGAIN]]

links.text: BEHIND YOU, THE MAN SPEAKS AGAIN

destination.name: BEHIND YOU, THE MAN SPEAKS AGAIN

passages.name: tabby
passages.text:
It's a girl with long ginger hair and a patched, too-small nightdress. At twelve or thirteen, she's the oldest one here.

[[SHE GIVES YOU A THIN, REASSURING SMILE AS THE MAN SPEAKS AGAIN|next]]

links.text: SHE GIVES YOU A THIN, REASSURING SMILE AS THE MAN SPEAKS AGAIN

passages.name: THE DOOR SLAMS BEHIND HIM
passages.text:
The other children stand frozen, watching the door, until his retreating footsteps have stopped shaking the walls. Then they all exhale as one.

[[THE GIRL – TABITHA – RELEASES YOUR HAND|dawn]]

links.text: THE GIRL – TABITHA – RELEASES YOUR HAND

passages.name: next
passages.text: Tabitha, show the new fish around and give it something to do. Something quiet. If you loathsome little toads wake me up before dinner I'll break your necks. [[THE DOOR SLAMS BEHIND HIM|ch1]]

passages.name: THE DOOR
passages.text:
Like the floor and walls, the door is just a few planks of wood held together with rusty nails. It doesn't have a lock or bolt. Not on the inside, anyway.
[[OPEN THE DOOR|OPEN IT]] <>THE WINDOW<>[[THE WINDOW]]<>
<>THE BEDS<>[[THE BEDS]]<> <>[[THE CHILDREN]]<>[[THE CHILDREN]]<>

passages.name: THE WINDOW
passages.text:
The window is a pitifully small square of thick, warped glass. You can't see much through the frost crystals still thawing on its outer face: a foggy morning settling over a rocky incline.
<>THE DOOR<>[[THE DOOR]]<> [[OPEN THE WINDOW|window]]
<>THE BEDS<>[[THE BEDS]]<> [[THE CHILDREN]]

passages.name: THE BEDS
passages.text:
'Beds' would be a very generous term. On the floorboards are a few piles of threadbare blankets. They don't smell like they've never been cleaned, but they don't exactly smell good, either. There's one pile for each of the four other children, and one spare. "That was where Claire slept," whispers Tabitha. "It's yours now."
<>THE DOOR<>[[THE DOOR]]<> <>THE WINDOW<>[[THE WINDOW]]<>
[[INVESTIGATE YOUR BED|bed]] <>[[THE CHILDREN]]<>[[THE CHILDREN]]<>

passages.name: THE CHILDREN
passages.text:
Apart from you, there are four other children in this room – two girls, two boys. They watch you with wide, uncertain eyes.
[[TALK TO TABITHA]] <>TALK TO HUMPHREY<>[[TALK TO HUMPHREY]]<>
<>TALK TO GRACE<>[[TALK TO GRACE]]<> <>TALK TO PETER<>[[TALK TO PETER]]<>

passages.name: OPEN IT
passages.text:
<<set $door = true>>The door squeaks on its hinges. The other children all jump to hold you back.

"There's a knack to doing it quietly," Tabitha whispers. "Lift while you pull, like this, see?"

[[SQUEAK SQUEAK]]

passages.name: SQUEAK SQUEAK
passages.text:
Tabitha shrugs. "You'll get the hang of it," she whispers.

[[SHE GLANCES NERVOUSLY AT THE DOOR|dawn]]

links.text: SHE GLANCES NERVOUSLY AT THE DOOR

passages.name: window
passages.text:
<<set $window = true>>It's locked.

[[THE LOCK IS THE MOST SUBSTANTIAL THING IN THE ROOM|dawn]]

links.text: THE LOCK IS THE MOST SUBSTANTIAL THING IN THE ROOM

passages.name: dawn
passages.text:
The light from the window is brighter now, and you can see your surroundings more clearly. There isn't much to see.
<>THE DOOR<>[[THE DOOR]]<> <>THE WINDOW<>[[THE WINDOW]]<>
<>THE BEDS<>[[THE BEDS]]<> <>[[THE CHILDREN]]<>[[THE CHILDREN]]<>

passages.name: bed
passages.text:
<>Among the rags of your new bed you find a small plastic comb. It's off-white with faded pink flowers, the letters "C.S.", and reddish hair tangled in its remaining teeth.
[[TAKE THE COMB]] [[LEAVE THE COMB]]

passages.name: TAKE THE COMB
passages.text:
<<set $gotcomb = true>>You slip the comb into your pocket. It's cold and grimy against your fingers.

[[IF THE OTHER CHILDREN NOTICE THEY DON'T SAY ANYTHING|dawn]]

links.text: IF THE OTHER CHILDREN NOTICE THEY DON'T SAY ANYTHING

passages.name: LEAVE THE COMB
passages.text:
You leave the comb on the floor beside your bed. It looks out of place in this room of dark greys and browns.

[[THE OTHER CHILDREN SAY NOTHING|dawn]]

passages.name: TALK TO HUMPHREY
passages.text:
<><><><>Humphrey looks you up and down. "This one //does// look like a fish," he pronounces, as loudly as he dares. "It almost makes me wish we had Claire back."
[[IGNORE HIM|dawn]] [[STICK OUT YOUR TONGUE]]

passages.name: TALK TO GRACE
passages.text:
<><><><>Grace is the youngest, a tiny girl with freckles and long eyelashes. She mouths a timid greeting before hiding her face in Tabitha's side.
[[PAT HER HEAD]] [[LEAVE HER ALONE|dawn]]

passages.name: TALK TO PETER
passages.text:
<><><><>Unlike the others in their pyjamas, Peter is wearing a drab school uniform with mismatched buttons. Which reminds you that you're currently missing school.
[[ASK ABOUT HIS CLOTHES]] [[IGNORE IT|dawn]]

passages.name: TALK TO TABITHA
passages.text:
<><><><>"When you're ready, I can show you around the rest of the house," she offers. Something about her voice makes you doubt it's going to be a bundle of laughs.
[[NOT YET|dawn]] [[I'M READY]]

passages.name: I'M READY
passages.text:
She leads you out onto a narrow, windowless landing. Through the gloom you see that there's only one other door. She points and whispers: "That's his room. Never go in there. Unless he tells you to." There's a trapdoor in the ceiling, and a flight of crooked stairs going down.
[[GO UP]] [[GO DOWN]]

passages.name: STICK OUT YOUR TONGUE
passages.text:
He glares and sticks out his tongue right back at you.

[[THE OTHERS LOOK UNCOMFORTABLE|dawn]]

passages.name: GO UP
passages.text:
You can't reach that high. Tabitha sees you looking and shakes her head. "Not today. Maybe later."
GO UP [[GO DOWN]]

passages.name: GO DOWN
passages.text:
You follow Tabitha down the stairs. She shows you where to step so they won't creak.

[[YOU DESCEND TO A LARGE KITCHEN|kitchen]]

links.text: YOU DESCEND TO A LARGE KITCHEN

passages.name: kitchen
passages.text:
<><><>The kitchen takes up the whole of the ground floor. There are two windows, which means more light, but the corners still crawl with shadows.
<>THE TABLE<>[[THE TABLE]]<> <>THE DOOR<>[[THE DOOR|THE KITCHEN DOOR]]<>
<>THE OVEN<>[[THE OVEN]]<> <>THE CUPBOARDS<>[[THE CUPBOARDS]]<>
<>

passages.name: THE TABLE
passages.text:
<<set $table = true>>The surface is scratched and worn, but clean. There's nothing resting on it except a single match, which Tabitha pockets.

There are six wooden chairs: five of them small, one of them – at the head of the table – huge. "You get Claire's old seat," says Tabitha, indicating the chair to the left of the big one.

[[IT LOOKS VERY UNCOMFORTABLE|kitchen]]

passages.name: THE KITCHEN DOOR
passages.text:
<<set $kitchendoor = true>>Through the front window you can see that the door leads straight onto a rocky hillside, sloping down away from the house. The only landmark is a copse of skeletal trees, half-lost in the mist.

"It's locked," explains Tabitha, "while he's asleep. Later he'll let us out to get wood and water and other things."

[[SHE DOESN'T SPECIFY WHAT OTHER THINGS]]

links.text: SHE DOESN'T SPECIFY WHAT OTHER THINGS

destination.name: SHE DOESN'T SPECIFY WHAT OTHER THINGS

passages.name: THE OVEN
passages.text:
<<set $oven = true>>There's a stack of firewood beside it and a row of pots and pans hanging up on the wall. The wide, flat top of the oven has been used as a hob, but right now it's cold, and there's a half-empty sack of raw potatoes lying spilled across it.

Tabitha sighs. "He's always hungry when he gets home," she explains, "but can't wait for one of us to make him a proper breakfast."

[[SHE TIDIES THE POTATOES AWAY|kitchen]]

passages.name: THE CUPBOARDS
passages.text:
<<set $cupboards = true>>Six plates – five small, one large – and the same assortment of bowls. Knives and forks and spoons of various shapes and sizes.

There's also food, some of it familiar, some not so much. Jars overflowing with oozes and wet shapes that might be vegetable or animal.

[[ALL OF IT SMELLS BAD|kitchen]]

passages.name: time
passages.text:
Peter comes downstairs and makes a beeline for something on the floor, tucked away in a corner. He straightens up with a look of dismay, holding the object out for you to see.

"Only one? And it's tiny," he groans. "It must be a juvenile. This won't do for dinner."

[[IT'S A HUGE MOUSETRAP WITH SOMETHING CAUGHT IN IT]]

links.text: IT'S A HUGE MOUSETRAP WITH SOMETHING CAUGHT IN IT

destination.name: IT'S A HUGE MOUSETRAP WITH SOMETHING CAUGHT IN IT

passages.name: IT'S A HUGE MOUSETRAP WITH SOMETHING CAUGHT IN IT
passages.text:
The dead animal looks sort of like a rat, but with a fleshy, elongated snout. It's bigger than any rat you've seen, but not big enough to feed six people.

"What are we going to do?" Peter seems on the brink of panic. "We can't serve him this. We can't go out and get more without waking him up. He's going to kill us."

[[TABITHA TAKES THE ANIMAL FROM HIM AND REMOVES IT FROM THE TRAP]]

links.text: TABITHA TAKES THE ANIMAL FROM HIM AND REMOVES IT FROM THE TRAP

destination.name: TABITHA TAKES THE ANIMAL FROM HIM AND REMOVES IT FROM THE TRAP

passages.name: TABITHA TAKES THE ANIMAL FROM HIM AND REMOVES IT FROM THE TRAP
passages.text:
"We'll just have to do what we can." She slaps it down on the table. "The first year I was here, half of them died of some disease. Some days we didn't catch anything. But we made do."

[[HOW]]

passages.name: PETER BRIGHTENS UP
passages.text:
He goes to a cupboard, takes out a jar, and puts it down next to the offending animal. "Blue things," he tells you, helpfully.

[[THE JAR IS FULL OF SLIMY BLUE-BLACK LUMPS]]

links.text: THE JAR IS FULL OF SLIMY BLUE-BLACK LUMPS

destination.name: THE JAR IS FULL OF SLIMY BLUE-BLACK LUMPS

passages.name: THE JAR IS FULL OF SLIMY BLUE-BLACK LUMPS
passages.text:
"We don't have to worry about dinner until this afternoon, anyway. In the meantime – chores." Tabitha and Peter set to work around the kitchen. They seem familiar with their tasks, moving almost automatically around the furniture and each other.
[[HELP TABITHA]] [[HELP PETER]]

passages.name: AFTER A WHILE, HUMPHREY AND GRACE COME DOWNSTAIRS
passages.text:
The five of you sit around the table and carve mould off a lump of bread for your lunch. All the others have the exact same way of eating – taking small bites and chewing steadily while staring down at their plates.
[[SAY SOMETHING]] [[EAT QUIETLY]]

passages.name: HELP TABITHA
passages.text:
<<set $helptabitha = true>>She looks at you gratefully as you help her to scrub snail trails and bootprints off the floor; clean gunk out of the water pump under the window; collect still-twitching insects off flypaper and sort them into bottles.

[[YOU MAKE A GOOD TEAM]]

passages.name: HELP PETER
passages.text:
<<set $helptabitha = false>>He looks at you gratefully as you help him to scrub snail trails and bootprints off the floor; clean gunk out of the water pump under the window; collect still-twitching insects off flypaper and sort them into bottles.

[[YOU MAKE A GOOD TEAM]]

passages.name: SAY SOMETHING
passages.text:
<>
[[WHAT HAVE YOU BEEN DOING UPSTAIRS]] [[WHAT IS THAT THING WE'RE HAVING FOR DINNER]]
[[WHAT IS THIS PLACE]] [[HOW DO I GET HOME]]

links.text: WHAT HAVE YOU BEEN DOING UPSTAIRS

destination.name: WHAT HAVE YOU BEEN DOING UPSTAIRS

links.text: WHAT IS THAT THING WE'RE HAVING FOR DINNER

destination.name: WHAT IS THAT THING WE'RE HAVING FOR DINNER

passages.name: EAT QUIETLY
passages.text:
<>Humphrey glances at you<> again<>, but addresses himself to the others. "So, how's the new fish settling in? Think it'll last long?" They all frown at him and keep chewing. Nobody says anything.
[[IGNORE HIM|IGNORE HIM 2]] [[KICK HIS SHINS]]

passages.name: WHAT HAVE YOU BEEN DOING UPSTAIRS
passages.text:
<<set $humphreyglance = true>>Humphrey just rolls his eyes. Grace takes care to swallow before answering in a tiny voice: "We've been mending his cloak. It's old so it tears easily, but we don't have enough material to make him a new one."

[[AND WHO IS HE EXACTLY]]

passages.name: WHAT IS THAT THING WE'RE HAVING FOR DINNER
passages.text:
<<set $humphreyglance = true>>Humphrey shrugs. "Dunno what they're called. They swarm in at night and try to get at the food, so we turn them into food. It's only fair."

[[DO THEY TASTE ANY GOOD]]

passages.name: WHAT IS THIS PLACE
passages.text:
<<set $humphreyglance = true>>Humphrey looks at you like you're stupid. "This is nowhere. This is //the house,"// he says, between mouthfuls of stale bread. "Well, //his// house. We're just the servants."

[[AND WHO IS HE EXACTLY]]

passages.name: HOW DO I GET HOME
passages.text:
Everybody keeps chewing in silence, but now it seems awkward, even forced. They all glance at Tabitha, but she's staring down at her plate harder than ever.

At last it's Grace who volunteers in a tiny voice: "He says we can go home when we've learned to be good."

[[AND WHO IS HE EXACTLY]]

passages.name: AND WHO IS HE EXACTLY
passages.text:
There's another awkward silence before Peter laughs nervously. "Your parents told you what happens to naughty children, right?"

[[YOU EAT YOUR BREAD|EAT QUIETLY]]

passages.name: DO THEY TASTE ANY GOOD
passages.text:
"They taste like dirt. Even he doesn't really like the taste, I think. He just loves knowing that they died trying to steal from him. And he says they're full of protein and," Humphrey fails to suppress an ironic drawl, //"we've got to learn to be grateful for what we have."//

[[AND WHO IS HE EXACTLY]]

passages.name: IGNORE HIM 2
passages.text:
"For the benefit of the new fish," Peter frowns in your direction, "we're not supposed to speak at mealtimes. Humphrey's setting a bad example."

"Speak when spoken to!" Grace pipes up, before realising she's broken the rule by its very utterance and clamping a hand over her own mouth in remorse.

[[YOU FINISH YOUR BREAD IN SILENCE|next1]]

links.text: YOU FINISH YOUR BREAD IN SILENCE

passages.name: KICK HIS SHINS
passages.text:
He flinches and scowls at you, but doesn't kick back.

[[HE SEEMS MORE SURPRISED THAN ANNOYED|IGNORE HIM 2]]

links.text: HE SEEMS MORE SURPRISED THAN ANNOYED

passages.name: MEANWHILE TABITHA BECKONS YOU OVER TO THE OVEN
passages.text:
You both squat down, and she starts showing you how to build the fire underneath. "We've got bones to boil for the broth tonight," she explains. "Takes a long time."

[[SHE TAKES THE MATCH OUT OF HER POCKET]]

links.text: SHE TAKES THE MATCH OUT OF HER POCKET

destination.name: SHE TAKES THE MATCH OUT OF HER POCKET

passages.name: SHE TAKES THE MATCH OUT OF HER POCKET
passages.text:
She hands it to you and indicates for you to strike it on the oven.

[[YOU FOLLOW HER MOTIONS|IT STRIKES AND CATCHES FIRST TIME]]

destination.name: IT STRIKES AND CATCHES FIRST TIME

passages.name: IT STRIKES AND CATCHES FIRST TIME
passages.text:
It strikes and catches first time. You hurry to light the kindling while Tabitha watches approvingly.

[[SOON THE FIRE IS BLAZING]]

passages.name: YOU'VE NEVER SMELLED SO MANY FLAVOURS OF BAD AT ONCE
passages.text:
The afternoon passes in a blur of industry. The broth gurgles with every ingredient added, every gelatinous juice, every chalky paste, every scrap of the rat-creature's meagre numbles.

[[EVERY SO OFTEN, A BONE BOBS TO THE SURFACE|YOU CAN'T BEGIN TO IMAGINE PUTTING IT IN YOUR MOUTH]]

links.text: EVERY SO OFTEN, A BONE BOBS TO THE SURFACE

destination.name: YOU CAN'T BEGIN TO IMAGINE PUTTING IT IN YOUR MOUTH

passages.name: YOU CAN'T BEGIN TO IMAGINE PUTTING IT IN YOUR MOUTH
passages.text:
By the time the fire is burning low and the boil has been reduced to a simmer, it's getting dark outside. Tabitha lights an oil lamp and places it in the middle of the table, from where it fills the room with quivering shadows.

[[YOU BEGIN TO WONDER IF HE WILL COME FOR HIS DINNER AFTER ALL]]

links.text: YOU BEGIN TO WONDER IF HE WILL COME FOR HIS DINNER AFTER ALL

destination.name: YOU BEGIN TO WONDER IF HE WILL COME FOR HIS DINNER AFTER ALL

passages.name: YOU BEGIN TO WONDER IF HE WILL COME FOR HIS DINNER AFTER ALL
passages.text:
Grace and Humphrey come downstairs again to help set the table. All four of them move slowly and carefully, like all this morning's anxiety is creeping back into their bodies.

[[FINALLY YOU HEAR A THUMP FROM UPSTAIRS]]

links.text: FINALLY YOU HEAR A THUMP FROM UPSTAIRS

destination.name: FINALLY YOU HEAR A THUMP FROM UPSTAIRS

passages.name: FINALLY YOU HEAR A THUMP FROM UPSTAIRS
passages.text:
Footsteps creak across the ceiling. He's making no effort to be quiet, though you get the feeling he could move more silently than any of you, if he chose to.

The other children all stand to attention behind their chairs. You follow suit just as he appears on the staircase.

[[HE BREATHES IN THE REEK OF THE FOOD AND NODS]]

links.text: HE BREATHES IN THE REEK OF THE FOOD AND NODS

destination.name: HE BREATHES IN THE REEK OF THE FOOD AND NODS

passages.name: HE BREATHES IN THE REEK OF THE FOOD AND NODS
passages.text:
You all wait while he takes his seat at the head of the table and casts a critical gaze over each of you in turn. His eyes are as hard and pale as bone. They linger longer on you than anyone else; it feels like he can see everything you've seen, knows everything you know.

[[AT LONG LAST HE RELEASES YOU WITH A GESTURE]]

links.text: AT LONG LAST HE RELEASES YOU WITH A GESTURE

destination.name: AT LONG LAST HE RELEASES YOU WITH A GESTURE

passages.name: AT LONG LAST HE RELEASES YOU WITH A GESTURE
passages.text:
Tabitha and Peter take their seats, while Humphrey and Grace get up to serve the broth. He ladles out the bowls, then she carries them to the table with care before setting them down.

[[SHE DELIVERS THE LARGEST BOWL FIRST]]

links.text: SHE DELIVERS THE LARGEST BOWL FIRST

destination.name: SHE DELIVERS THE LARGEST BOWL FIRST

passages.name: next1
passages.text:
Peter starts clearing away the plates. Grace rushes to help him wash them under the pump, while Humphrey slips back upstairs.

[[MEANWHILE TABITHA BECKONS YOU OVER TO THE OVEN]]

links.text: MEANWHILE TABITHA BECKONS YOU OVER TO THE OVEN

destination.name: MEANWHILE TABITHA BECKONS YOU OVER TO THE OVEN

passages.name: SHE DELIVERS THE LARGEST BOWL FIRST
passages.text:
From your position, you can see that Humphrey has served him easily the majority of the animal parts, and a surplus of blue things.

When your own bowl arrives, it is relatively (and mercifully) free of any substance at all – it looks more like compromised water than food.

[[WHEN EVERYONE HAS BEEN SERVED, GRACE AND HUMPHREY TAKE THEIR SEATS]]

links.text: WHEN EVERYONE HAS BEEN SERVED, GRACE AND HUMPHREY TAKE THEIR SEATS

destination.name: WHEN EVERYONE HAS BEEN SERVED, GRACE AND HUMPHREY TAKE THEIR SEATS

passages.name: WHEN EVERYONE HAS BEEN SERVED, GRACE AND HUMPHREY TAKE THEIR SEATS
passages.text: They bow their heads, which you take as a prompt to do the same. We are truly grateful for what we have. [[WE ARE TRULY GRATEFUL FOR WHAT WE HAVE|THE CHILDREN ECHO HIM IN UNISON]]

links.text: WE ARE TRULY GRATEFUL FOR WHAT WE HAVE

destination.name: THE CHILDREN ECHO HIM IN UNISON

passages.name: THE CHILDREN ECHO HIM IN UNISON
passages.text:
And with no further ceremony, everyone starts eating. The children eat like they did at lunchtime: small, controlled sips, watching their bowls like they might try to run away.

[[HE EATS LIKE A DOG IF A DOG COULD HOLD A SPOON]]

links.text: HE EATS LIKE A DOG IF A DOG COULD HOLD A SPOON

destination.name: HE EATS LIKE A DOG IF A DOG COULD HOLD A SPOON

passages.name: HE EATS LIKE A DOG IF A DOG COULD HOLD A SPOON
passages.text:
He makes more noise eating than he does talking. You take the opportunity to look at him properly, while he's distracted –

[[THE BOGEYMAN]]

passages.name: THE BOGEYMAN
passages.text:
Without the robes, you can see he's wearing a sort of long-sleeved black tunic, unbuttoned to halfway down his chest. The skin underneath is white.

[[SOMEHOW IT LOOKS LIKE IT MIGHT START OOZING ANYTHING AT ANY MOMENT]]

links.text: SOMEHOW IT LOOKS LIKE IT MIGHT START OOZING ANYTHING AT ANY MOMENT

destination.name: SOMEHOW IT LOOKS LIKE IT MIGHT START OOZING ANYTHING AT ANY MOMENT

passages.name: REMEMBER TO DRINK YOUR OWN BROTH
passages.text:
Perhaps a little part of you trusted in Tabitha and Peter to make it work, to assemble their foul ingredients into something palatable, even delicious.

[[EVERY SPOONFUL MAKES YOU GAG]]

passages.name: EVERY SPOONFUL MAKES YOU GAG
passages.text:
You're still battling your way through your serving when he sends Tabitha up to bring him seconds. By the time you finish, he's drinking the dregs straight from the bowl.

[[HE BANGS HIS EMPTY BOWL DOWN ON THE TABLE AND GROWLS]]

links.text: HE BANGS HIS EMPTY BOWL DOWN ON THE TABLE AND GROWLS

destination.name: HE BANGS HIS EMPTY BOWL DOWN ON THE TABLE AND GROWLS

passages.name: HE BANGS HIS EMPTY BOWL DOWN ON THE TABLE AND GROWLS
passages.text: What the hell was that? Where was the meat? [[NOBODY SAYS A WORD]]

passages.name: NOBODY SAYS A WORD
passages.text:
Well? Did anyone hear me? He grabs you by the ear. His nails feel sharp enough to draw blood. <>You've been pretty chatty today, haven't you, little fish? So chat to me.<>You've been awfully quiet all day, little fish. Let's hear what you have to say.<> Where's the meat? Did you hoard it all for yourself, hmm?
[[THERE WASN'T ENOUGH TO GO AROUND]] [[YOU GOT MORE THAN YOUR FAIR SHARE]]

links.text: THERE WASN'T ENOUGH TO GO AROUND

destination.name: THERE WASN'T ENOUGH TO GO AROUND

links.text: YOU GOT MORE THAN YOUR FAIR SHARE

destination.name: YOU GOT MORE THAN YOUR FAIR SHARE

passages.name: YOU GOT MORE THAN YOUR FAIR SHARE
passages.text: <>He yanks you sideways off your chair, which clatters to the ground. Your head starts swimming as he drags you towards the door. You don't get to decide what's fair. Flecks of broth land in your face. I decide what's fair. [[HE TAKES AN IRON KEY OUT OF HIS POCKET]]

links.text: HE TAKES AN IRON KEY OUT OF HIS POCKET

destination.name: HE TAKES AN IRON KEY OUT OF HIS POCKET

passages.name: THERE WASN'T ENOUGH TO GO AROUND
passages.text: I don't want your excuses, he spits. I want meat. [[HE RISES TO HIS FEET]]

passages.name: HE TAKES AN IRON KEY OUT OF HIS POCKET
passages.text: <>You won't last very long around here if you don't start showing some respect, he hisses, still holding you fast with one hand while he unlocks the door. So here's what's going to happen.<>You won't last very long around here if you don't start taking responsibility for your mistakes, he hisses, still holding you fast with one hand while he unlocks the door. So here's what's going to happen.<> [[A COLD, WILD NIGHT SWEEPS INTO THE WARM KITCHEN]]

links.text: A COLD, WILD NIGHT SWEEPS INTO THE WARM KITCHEN

destination.name: A COLD, WILD NIGHT SWEEPS INTO THE WARM KITCHEN

passages.name: HE RISES TO HIS FEET
passages.text:
You stumble after as he drags you towards the door. The other children keep their eyes fixed on their empty bowls.

[[HE TAKES AN IRON KEY OUT OF HIS POCKET]]

links.text: HE TAKES AN IRON KEY OUT OF HIS POCKET

destination.name: HE TAKES AN IRON KEY OUT OF HIS POCKET

passages.name: A COLD, WILD NIGHT SWEEPS INTO THE WARM KITCHEN
passages.text: You are going to go and find me something to eat. He thrusts you into the darkness. Now the light of the kitchen seems blinding, framing his dark bulk in the doorway. Behind him, you can see the other children still averting their eyes. [[GRACE LOOKS LIKE SHE'S HOLDING BACK TEARS]]

links.text: GRACE LOOKS LIKE SHE'S HOLDING BACK TEARS

destination.name: GRACE LOOKS LIKE SHE'S HOLDING BACK TEARS

passages.name: GRACE LOOKS LIKE SHE'S HOLDING BACK TEARS
passages.text: And be quick about it. If you dare come back empty-handed, you'll be the one going hungry tomorrow. [[THE DOOR SLAMS SHUT]]

passages.name: THE DOOR SLAMS SHUT
passages.text:
And you are left alone in the moonless night, with the wind whipping at your pyjamas and rain beginning to spit at your skin.

[[LOOK AROUND]]

passages.name: LOOK AROUND
passages.text:
You're on a blasted hillside, all jagged rocks and mud. From outside, the house – more like a hovel, really – is little more than a pile of sticks and slate. The glow from the window only lets you see a few steps in any direction. As soon as you stray any further, you will be travelling almost blind.
[[WALK UPWARDS]] [[WALK DOWNWARDS]]

passages.name: WALK UPWARDS
passages.text:
<<set $timewaster = true>>You stagger around to the back of the building and set off up the hill. Every footstep lands either on a sharp edge of rock, or on something slimy and unspeakable.

You navigate by the angle of the ground and the rain, and by the distant glow of the kitchen's rear window when you glance over your shoulder. You press on until the window is no more a pinprick, and then on, and on.

[[AND ON AND ON]]

passages.name: WALK DOWNWARDS
passages.text:
You stagger away from the house. Every footstep lands either on a sharp edge of rock, or on something slimy and unspeakable.

You navigate by the angle of the ground and the rain, and by the distant glow of the kitchen window when you glance over your shoulder. You press on until the window is no more a pinprick, and then on, and on.

[[AND THEN SOMETHING WHIPS AGAINST YOUR FACE]]

links.text: AND THEN SOMETHING WHIPS AGAINST YOUR FACE

destination.name: AND THEN SOMETHING WHIPS AGAINST YOUR FACE

passages.name: AND THEN SOMETHING WHIPS AGAINST YOUR FACE
passages.text:
You push it away and feel damp bark peeling under your fingers. You've reached the edge of the copse without even seeing it. Now that you're here, you can make out the towering shapes of trees around you, skeletons in black against the black.
[[GO ON]] [[TURN BACK]]

passages.name: AND ON AND ON
passages.text:
Your feet only stop hurting when they go numb. The rain is coming down harder now, drenching your pyjamas and your hair, catching in your eyelashes, streaming down your face.

[[STUMBLE]]

passages.name: STUMBLE
passages.text:
The rocks, already mottled with moss, are getting slippery in the downpour. Your foot slides backwards and sends you sprawling, scraping your hands and legs and cracking your chin on the ground.<<if $gotrat or $gotbird>>

As you throw your hands out to save yourself, the <<if $gotrat>>rat-thing jumps free and scurries away into the night.<<set $gotrat = false>><<else>>chick flutters out of your hands and disappears. Whether it flew back to its nest, or was snatched away by the wind, it's hard to say.<<set $gotbird = false>><<endif>><<endif>>

[[YOUR EARS ARE RINGING]]

passages.name: YOUR EARS ARE RINGING
passages.text:
You can't hear anything else over the roar of the weather. Nothing to suggest you're any closer to finding – anything at all, except more wasteland.
[[GO UP|GO UP 2]] [[GO DOWN|GO DOWN 2]]

passages.name: GO UP 2
passages.text:
You limp onwards. The higher you go, the sharper and more treacherous the rocks become. Are your feet bleeding or just wet?
[[GO UP|GO UP 3]] [[GO DOWN|GO DOWN 2]]

passages.name: GO DOWN 2
passages.text:
You limp back the way you came. At least gravity is on your side now.

Once the faint light of the kitchen window comes into view, it gets easier to just keep pressing towards it.

[[EVENTUALLY YOU'RE BACK WHERE YOU STARTED]]

links.text: EVENTUALLY YOU'RE BACK WHERE YOU STARTED

destination.name: EVENTUALLY YOU'RE BACK WHERE YOU STARTED

passages.name: GO ON
passages.text:
<<set $entercopse = true>>You press into the thicket. The scent of rotting leaves rises up around you.

[[AND THE SCENT OF ANIMAL LIFE]]

links.text: AND THE SCENT OF ANIMAL LIFE

destination.name: AND THE SCENT OF ANIMAL LIFE

passages.name: TURN BACK
passages.text:
You turn around and stumble back the way you came. Your feet are numb with cold and your legs stiff, but the light of the window growing larger and brighter keeps you in motion.

[[EVENTUALLY YOU'RE BACK WHERE YOU STARTED]]

links.text: EVENTUALLY YOU'RE BACK WHERE YOU STARTED

destination.name: EVENTUALLY YOU'RE BACK WHERE YOU STARTED

passages.name: AND THE SCENT OF ANIMAL LIFE
passages.text:
You're more sheltered from the weather here, but prodded at by the trees on all sides. Twigs catch at your pyjamas and scratch at your scalp and snap against your ankles with every movement.
[[EXAMINE THE TREES]] [[EXAMINE THE GROUND]]
[[LEAVE THE COPSE]]

passages.name: SHE DOESN'T SPECIFY WHAT OTHER THINGS
passages.text:
Her eyes grow dark. "I don't know why he bothers locking it, anyway. We're not really – //anywhere// right now. You know? It's not like you could just keep walking until you got back to the real world. It's – it's complicated."

[[SHE SIGHS|kitchen]]

passages.name: HOW
passages.text:
"We'll use all the organs, and the tail. And throw in lots of the blue things. He likes the blue things."

[[PETER BRIGHTENS UP]]

passages.name: EXAMINE THE TREES
passages.text:
<>You grope around with your free hand, but you don't find anything useful.
EXAMINE THE TREES [[EXAMINE THE GROUND]]
[[LEAVE THE COPSE]]
\ <>You grope around until <>you find that sturdy branch again. It's slippery but it could take your weight, if you're careful.<>your hand comes to rest on a sturdy branch, about waist-height. It's slippery but it could take your weight, if you're careful.<>
[[CLIMB]] [[DON'T CLIMB]]
<>

passages.name: EXAMINE THE GROUND
passages.text:
<>You hunker down, groping about the undergrowth with your free hand, but you don't find anything useful.
[[EXAMINE THE TREES]] EXAMINE THE GROUND
[[LEAVE THE COPSE]]
\ <>You hunker down, groping about the undergrowth and roots and soil with fingers stiffened by cold. <>After a minute of searching, you find the hole in the earth again.<>After a few minutes, your hand disappears into a hole where you expected to find earth.<>
[[REACH DEEPER]] [[PULL BACK]]
<>

passages.name: REACH DEEPER
passages.text:
<><>You sink your hand further into the burrow, but there's nothing there anymore.
REACH DEEPER [[PULL BACK]]
<>You sink your hand further into the burrow until it closes on something warm and soft and trembling.
[[GRAB]] [[RECOIL]]
<>

passages.name: PULL BACK
passages.text:
<>You withdraw your hand, leaving the creature to cower in its burrow.
[[EXAMINE THE TREES]] [[EXAMINE THE GROUND]]
[[LEAVE THE COPSE]]

passages.name: LEAVE THE COPSE
passages.text:
You feel your way back out into the open. You know you're out of the trees when you feel the full force of the rain on your face.<> Your captive animal scratches and struggles feebly.<>
[[GO UP|up from copse]] [[GO DOWN|down from copse]]

passages.name: GRAB
passages.text:
<<set $touchedrat = true>><<set $gotrat = true>><<set $tookrat = true>>Your hand closes around the creature until you can feel its little heart pounding. You pull it out of the ground and hold it close.

It's a rat creature, like the one from the trap, but even smaller. It makes an angry hooting noise as you cup it between your hands.

[[LEAVE THE COPSE]]

passages.name: RECOIL
passages.text:
<>You withdraw your hand, leaving the creature to cower in its burrow.
[[EXAMINE THE TREES]] [[EXAMINE THE GROUND]]
[[LEAVE THE COPSE]]

passages.name: up from copse
passages.text:
You stumble up the hill. It's not long before the light of the hovel becomes visible again and grows brighter with every step.

[[SOON YOU'RE BACK WHERE YOU STARTED|EVENTUALLY YOU'RE BACK WHERE YOU STARTED]]

links.text: SOON YOU'RE BACK WHERE YOU STARTED

destination.name: EVENTUALLY YOU'RE BACK WHERE YOU STARTED

passages.name: down from copse
passages.text:
<>You carry on down the hill, leaving the shelter of the trees and the hovel far behind you.<> It's harder to keep balance with your hands full. Every step is a struggle to stay upright.<>
[[GO UP|THE COPSE]] [[GO DOWN|GO DOWN 5]]

passages.name: EVENTUALLY YOU'RE BACK WHERE YOU STARTED
passages.text:
Through the window, you can see bowls all washed and hung up above the sink to drip dry. The five small chairs are empty now; the bogeyman sits alone at the head of the table, swigging something dark out of a bottle.
[[GO UP|WALK UPWARDS]] [[GO DOWN|WALK DOWNWARDS]]
[[KNOCK]]

passages.name: GO UP 3
passages.text:
Every breath hurts like a knife in the ribs.
[[GO UP|GO UP 4]] [[GO DOWN|GO DOWN 2]]

passages.name: GO UP 4
passages.text:
You fall again, and this time there's no getting up.

Right before your eyes force themselves shut, you think you see something.

[[LIKE A LIGHT IN THE SKY UP AHEAD]]

links.text: LIKE A LIGHT IN THE SKY UP AHEAD

destination.name: LIKE A LIGHT IN THE SKY UP AHEAD

passages.name: LIKE A LIGHT IN THE SKY UP AHEAD
passages.text:
<<timed 2s t8n>><<set $passout = true>>The next thing you know, you're back in your chair in the kitchen. The fire is burning low and there's nobody else around except the Bogeyman standing over you, drinking something black out of a black bottle.

[[HE SHAKES HIS HEAD WHEN HE SEES YOU'RE COMING ROUND]]<</timed>>

links.text: HE SHAKES HIS HEAD WHEN HE SEES YOU'RE COMING ROUND

destination.name: HE SHAKES HIS HEAD WHEN HE SEES YOU'RE COMING ROUND

passages.name: CLIMB
passages.text:
<<set $foundtree = true>><<set $climb = true>>You bounce up on your palms and hitch one leg over the branch. Hugging the trunk for support, you manage to raise yourself on wobbly legs until you're standing straight.

[[YOU REACH UP|YOUR HAND TRAVELS UPWARDS]]

passages.name: DON'T CLIMB
passages.text:
You ignore the tree. You're surrounded by more on all sides, though none of the others seem scalable.
[[EXAMINE THE TREES]] [[EXAMINE THE GROUND]]
[[LEAVE THE COPSE]]

passages.name: YOUR HAND TRAVELS UPWARDS
passages.text:
<>You find the nest of twigs again. It's empty. [[CLIMB DOWN]]<>You touch something nestled among the higher branches. A nest of scratchy twigs, and inside – soft feathers, one sharp little beak.
[[GRAB|grab bird]] [[RECOIL|recoil bird]]
<>

passages.name: grab bird
passages.text:
<<set $gotbird = true>><<set $tookbird = true>>Your fist closes around the chick until you can feel its tiny heart hammering against your fingers. Only when you bring it close to your face can you hear the furious peeping noise it's making.

[[CLIMB DOWN|climb down w bird]]

passages.name: recoil bird
passages.text:
You pull back your hand, leaving the chick to itself. There's no sign of any adults rushing to protect it.
[[CLIMB DOWN]] [[REACH UP|YOUR HAND TRAVELS UPWARDS]]

passages.name: CLIMB DOWN
passages.text:
You lower yourself out of the tree. You're surrounded by more on all sides, though none of the others seem scalable.
[[EXAMINE THE TREES]] [[EXAMINE THE GROUND]]
[[LEAVE THE COPSE]]

passages.name: climb down w bird
passages.text:
You lower yourself out of the tree, cradling the chick to your chest.

[[LEAVE THE COPSE]]

passages.name: KNOCK
passages.text:
<>You tap on the door with one hand, hoping to be heard over the wind and rain, and keep your captive animal clutched safe in the other. Inside, you hear the bogeyman rise and stomp across the kitchen floor. The <>rat<>bird<>'s struggles have subsided to a helpless quivering.
[[RELEASE IT]] [[WAIT]]
<>You tap on the door, hoping to be heard over the wind and rain. [[YOU HEAR THE BOGEYMAN RISE AND STOMP ACROSS THE KITCHEN FLOOR|WAIT]]<>

links.text: YOU HEAR THE BOGEYMAN RISE AND STOMP ACROSS THE KITCHEN FLOOR

passages.name: RELEASE IT
passages.text:
At the last moment, you open your hands and your prize <<if $gotrat>>scurries<<else>>flutters<<endif>> away into the darkness.

[[THE DOOR OPENS|release]]

passages.name: WAIT
passages.text:
You stand there in the wind and rain, readying yourself.

[[THE DOOR OPENS]]

passages.name: THE DOOR OPENS
passages.text: The Bogeyman lifts you over the threshold by the scruff of your rain-soaked pyjamas. Well well. Look what the storm washed up. [[HE SHUTS THE DOOR AGAINST THE NIGHT]]

links.text: HE SHUTS THE DOOR AGAINST THE NIGHT

destination.name: HE SHUTS THE DOOR AGAINST THE NIGHT

passages.name: HE SHUTS THE DOOR AGAINST THE NIGHT
passages.text:
It's not especially warm or bright inside the hovel, but compared to the hillside it's not bad. With the muffled roar of the weather against the windows, it could almost be described as cosy.

[[HE DROPS INTO HIS CHAIR AND TAKES ANOTHER SLUG OF MYSTERY JUICE]]

links.text: HE DROPS INTO HIS CHAIR AND TAKES ANOTHER SLUG OF MYSTERY JUICE

destination.name: HE DROPS INTO HIS CHAIR AND TAKES ANOTHER SLUG OF MYSTERY JUICE

passages.name: HE DROPS INTO HIS CHAIR AND TAKES ANOTHER SLUG OF MYSTERY JUICE
passages.text: <>You took your sweet time out there, fish. The rest have all drunk their milk and gone to bed. I had to give little Gracie extra to stop her snivelling. <>You were pretty quick, fish. I'm pleasantly surprised. He does look pleased, even though there's nothing pleasant about it. The rest have only just drunk their milk and gone to bed. I had to give little Gracie extra to stop her snivelling. <>[[HIS TONGUE LOLLS OUT, HUGE AND BLACKENED BY THE DRINK]]

links.text: HIS TONGUE LOLLS OUT, HUGE AND BLACKENED BY THE DRINK

destination.name: HIS TONGUE LOLLS OUT, HUGE AND BLACKENED BY THE DRINK

passages.name: givefood
passages.text:
You hold your hands out over the table and open them just enough for your prize to peek its tiny head out.

[[HE SNATCHES IT]]

passages.name: nofood
passages.text:
You show him your hands, scratched and raw with cold, but empty.

[[HE SCOWLS]]

passages.name: HE SNATCHES IT
passages.text: And stuffs it into his mouth without ceremony. Not bad, he declares, <>slurping up the still-squirming tail,<>spraying feathers.<> A bit small, but at least I won't go to bed hungry. [[EACH WORD IS ACCOMPANIED BY A SERIES OF IMPOSSIBLY LOUD CRUNCHES]]

links.text: EACH WORD IS ACCOMPANIED BY A SERIES OF IMPOSSIBLY LOUD CRUNCHES

destination.name: EACH WORD IS ACCOMPANIED BY A SERIES OF IMPOSSIBLY LOUD CRUNCHES

passages.name: EACH WORD IS ACCOMPANIED BY A SERIES OF IMPOSSIBLY LOUD CRUNCHES
passages.text: You're off to a good start, fish. Just do as I say, that's all there is to it. Keep it up and you'll soon be on your way home. [[HE SWALLOWS IT, BONES AND ALL, AND BELCHES]]

links.text: HE SWALLOWS IT, BONES AND ALL, AND BELCHES

destination.name: HE SWALLOWS IT, BONES AND ALL, AND BELCHES

passages.name: HE SWALLOWS IT, BONES AND ALL, AND BELCHES
passages.text: <>He grins contentedly at you. His teeth are stained red now as well as black. Run along to bed, then. Long day tomorrow. I've got this to finish, he adds, gesturing to the bottle. [[GO TO BED]]

passages.name: HE SCOWLS
passages.text:
I told you to bring me meat, you stupid brat, not mess around on the hillside and keep me waiting here for nothing.
[[I'LL DO BETTER NEXT TIME]] [[IT WAS IMPOSSIBLE]]

passages.name: I'LL DO BETTER NEXT TIME
passages.text:
{{{Yes you will, if you ever want to go home. There's only one rule around here, and that's to do as you're told, so get that through your skull as early as possible.}}}

[[HE DRAINS THE LAST OF THE BLACK LIQUID]]

links.text: HE DRAINS THE LAST OF THE BLACK LIQUID

destination.name: HE DRAINS THE LAST OF THE BLACK LIQUID

passages.name: IT WAS IMPOSSIBLE
passages.text:
{{{Stop making excuses. If you ever want to get back home, you're going to have to learn to do as you're told, and do it without complaining.}}}

[[HE DRAINS THE LAST OF THE BLACK LIQUID]]

links.text: HE DRAINS THE LAST OF THE BLACK LIQUID

destination.name: HE DRAINS THE LAST OF THE BLACK LIQUID

passages.name: HE DRAINS THE LAST OF THE BLACK LIQUID
passages.text:
<<set $nofood = true>>{{{No food for you tomorrow, then,}}} he sighs, abandoning the empty bottle and casting about for another. {{{Now go to bed. Go on, get out of my sight.}}}

[[GO TO BED]]

passages.name: GO TO BED
passages.text:
It would be nice to warm and dry yourself beside the embers of the fire for a while, but the Bogeyman doesn't seem to care that you're still shivering.

[[YOU TURN AND CLIMB THE STAIRS, GRIPPING THE WALL FOR SUPPORT]]

links.text: YOU TURN AND CLIMB THE STAIRS, GRIPPING THE WALL FOR SUPPORT

destination.name: YOU TURN AND CLIMB THE STAIRS, GRIPPING THE WALL FOR SUPPORT

passages.name: YOU TURN AND CLIMB THE STAIRS, GRIPPING THE WALL FOR SUPPORT
passages.text:
Your legs don't give out until you're inside the bedroom. You sink to your knees, feeling the rough wooden floor beneath you, like you did this morning.

In the darkness, you can hear the slow breathing of the other children, already asleep in their own corners of the room.

[[FIND YOUR OWN BED]]

passages.name: FIND YOUR OWN BED
passages.text:
After a period of careful searching and a few accidental encounters with warm bodies, you locate a small pile of rags with no occupant. This must be where – what did they say her name was? – where Claire used to sleep.

[[CURL UP AND TRY TO GET WARM]]

links.text: CURL UP AND TRY TO GET WARM

destination.name: CURL UP AND TRY TO GET WARM

passages.name: CURL UP AND TRY TO GET WARM
passages.text:
You pull the largest piece of blanket over you, and your arm goes straight through a hole. It takes a few more minutes of shuffling and rearranging, but eventually you've more or less covered yourself.

[[YOU FEEL SOMETHING SMALL JAB AGAINST YOUR HIP]]

links.text: YOU FEEL SOMETHING SMALL JAB AGAINST YOUR HIP

destination.name: YOU FEEL SOMETHING SMALL JAB AGAINST YOUR HIP

passages.name: YOU FEEL SOMETHING SMALL JAB AGAINST YOUR HIP
passages.text: <><>It's the plastic comb you took from your bed this morning, still in your pocket, now pressed awkwardly between your body and the floor. You take it out and lay it beside you.<>It's the plastic comb you found in your bed this morning, still here among the rags. You retrieve it and lay it on the floor beside you.<><>You dig it out from underneath yourself and examine the shape of it in the dark. It's a small plastic comb, with a few strands of hair tangled in its remaining teeth. You lay it on the floor beside you. <> [[CLAIRE'S COMB]]

passages.name: CLAIRE'S COMB
passages.text:
Maybe she was hoping for her parents to give her a new one when she got home, a better one. Or maybe she just left in a hurry. It's not like the Bogeyman gave you any time to pack your bags when he brought you here.

[[MAYBE SHE LEFT IT BEHIND AS A GIFT]]

links.text: MAYBE SHE LEFT IT BEHIND AS A GIFT

destination.name: MAYBE SHE LEFT IT BEHIND AS A GIFT

passages.name: MAYBE SHE LEFT IT BEHIND AS A GIFT
passages.text:
You close your eyes and clutch the rags close about you until you've almost stopped shivering. The sound of rain against the window and the steady breathing of your fellow prisoners helps to quiet your thoughts until at last,

[[YOUR EXHAUSTION PULLS YOU INTO A DEEP, DREAMLESS SLEEP]]

links.text: YOUR EXHAUSTION PULLS YOU INTO A DEEP, DREAMLESS SLEEP

destination.name: YOUR EXHAUSTION PULLS YOU INTO A DEEP, DREAMLESS SLEEP

passages.name: YOUR EXHAUSTION PULLS YOU INTO A DEEP, DREAMLESS SLEEP
passages.text: <<goto "fadeout" t8n>>

passages.name: DAY 2a
passages.text: <

passages.name: WAKE UP
passages.text:
<<if $helptabitha>>You open your eyes to find Tabitha shaking you gently. "Morning."

[[SHE SMILES TO SEE YOU AWAKE]]\
\
<<else>>You open your eyes to find Peter shaking you gently. "Morning."

[[HE SMILES TO SEE YOU AWAKE|SHE SMILES TO SEE YOU AWAKE]]<<endif>>

links.text: SHE SMILES TO SEE YOU AWAKE

destination.name: SHE SMILES TO SEE YOU AWAKE

links.text: HE SMILES TO SEE YOU AWAKE

destination.name: SHE SMILES TO SEE YOU AWAKE

passages.name: HIS TONGUE LOLLS OUT, HUGE AND BLACKENED BY THE DRINK
passages.text: I hope you brought me something tasty. <>[[SHOW HIM|givefood]]<>[[SHOW HIM|nofood]]<>

passages.name: SHE SMILES TO SEE YOU AWAKE
passages.text:
"I hope you're feeling better after last night! Lots to do today." The window is already brightening with the dawn, and the other children are nowhere to be seen.

<<if $helptabitha>>[[TABITHA HELPS YOU TO YOUR FEET]]<<else>>[[PETER HELPS YOU TO YOUR FEET|TABITHA HELPS YOU TO YOUR FEET]]<<endif>>

links.text: TABITHA HELPS YOU TO YOUR FEET

destination.name: TABITHA HELPS YOU TO YOUR FEET

links.text: PETER HELPS YOU TO YOUR FEET

destination.name: TABITHA HELPS YOU TO YOUR FEET

passages.name: TABITHA HELPS YOU TO YOUR FEET
passages.text:
The two of you make your way down to the kitchen, where Humphrey has just finished setting the table for breakfast. Grace is asleep on her feet behind her chair.

[[THE BOGEYMAN IS ALREADY SEATED AND CHEWING]]

links.text: THE BOGEYMAN IS ALREADY SEATED AND CHEWING

destination.name: THE BOGEYMAN IS ALREADY SEATED AND CHEWING

passages.name: THE BOGEYMAN IS ALREADY SEATED AND CHEWING
passages.text: I woke up starving after that second-rate dinner yesterday, he announces around a mouthful of toast. <>Which reminds me – he gestures to you – no food for this one today until it learns to behave.<>You have to suppress a shudder when he winks at you.<> [[YOU ALL TAKE YOUR PLACES BEHIND YOUR CHAIRS]]

links.text: YOU ALL TAKE YOUR PLACES BEHIND YOUR CHAIRS

destination.name: YOU ALL TAKE YOUR PLACES BEHIND YOUR CHAIRS

passages.name: YOU ALL TAKE YOUR PLACES BEHIND YOUR CHAIRS
passages.text: We are truly grateful for what we have. [[WE ARE TRULY GRATEFUL FOR WHAT WE HAVE|WE ARE TRULY GRATEFUL FOR WHAT WE HAVE2]]

links.text: WE ARE TRULY GRATEFUL FOR WHAT WE HAVE

destination.name: WE ARE TRULY GRATEFUL FOR WHAT WE HAVE2

passages.name: WE ARE TRULY GRATEFUL FOR WHAT WE HAVE2
passages.text:
You all sit down. Apart from the toast, there's some kind of<<if not $nofood>> tasteless<<endif>> grey matter – if you had to compare it to anything, you'd choose scrambled eggs.

<<if $nofood>>[[YOU WATCH THE OTHERS EAT AND CAN'T FIND IT IN YOU TO ENVY THEM MUCH|breakfast]]<<else>>[[YOU EAT AS MUCH AS YOU CAN STOMACH|breakfast]]<<endif>>

links.text: YOU WATCH THE OTHERS EAT AND CAN'T FIND IT IN YOU TO ENVY THEM MUCH
YOU EAT AS MUCH AS YOU CAN STOMACH

passages.name: breakfast
passages.text:
When everyone's finished, the Bogeyman dismisses the other children, who all rise to clear away their plates. Except Grace, who has fallen asleep again.
[[NUDGE HER]] [[TAKE HER PLATE]]
[[LEAVE HER BE]]

passages.name: NUDGE HER
passages.text:
The Bogeyman is preparing a smack to the back of Grace's head. He frowns when you rouse her with a nudge before he can deliver it.

[[SHE JOLTS TO HER FEET AND HURRIES TO CLEAR AWAY HER PLATE|GRACE HURRIES TO CLEAR AWAY HER PLATE]]

links.text: SHE JOLTS TO HER FEET AND HURRIES TO CLEAR AWAY HER PLATE

destination.name: GRACE HURRIES TO CLEAR AWAY HER PLATE

passages.name: TAKE HER PLATE
passages.text:
You go to take Grace's plate for her, but the Bogeyman smacks your hand away. {{{Move when I tell you to move,}}} he snaps, and rouses Grace himself with a clip across the ear. {{{That goes for both of you. Grace! Move!}}}

[[SHE JOLTS TO HER FEET AND HURRIES TO CLEAR AWAY HER PLATE|GRACE HURRIES TO CLEAR AWAY HER PLATE]]

links.text: SHE JOLTS TO HER FEET AND HURRIES TO CLEAR AWAY HER PLATE

destination.name: GRACE HURRIES TO CLEAR AWAY HER PLATE

passages.name: LEAVE HER BE
passages.text:
You sit quietly as the Bogeyman reaches over to rouse Grace with a smack to the back of the head.

[[SHE JOLTS TO HER FEET AND HURRIES TO CLEAR AWAY HER PLATE|GRACE HURRIES TO CLEAR AWAY HER PLATE]]

links.text: SHE JOLTS TO HER FEET AND HURRIES TO CLEAR AWAY HER PLATE

destination.name: GRACE HURRIES TO CLEAR AWAY HER PLATE

passages.name: GRACE HURRIES TO CLEAR AWAY HER PLATE
passages.text:
{{{Maybe we gave her a little too much milk last night. Then again,}}} he points at you, {{{you didn't have any at all, and you slept in later than anyone. Don't worry, we'll soon knock the laziness out of you.}}}

[[HE YAWNS AND STRETCHES]]

passages.name: YOU MAKE A GOOD TEAM
passages.text:
<<if $helptabitha>>She shows you how to do it all quietly, and how to return everything to its proper place. Untidiness is just as bad as noisiness, she warns.<<else>>He shows you how to do it all quietly, and how to return everything to its proper place. Untidiness is just as bad as noisiness, he warns.<<endif>>

[[AFTER A WHILE, HUMPHREY AND GRACE COME DOWNSTAIRS]]

links.text: AFTER A WHILE, HUMPHREY AND GRACE COME DOWNSTAIRS

destination.name: AFTER A WHILE, HUMPHREY AND GRACE COME DOWNSTAIRS

passages.name: HE YAWNS AND STRETCHES
passages.text:
{{{You're all on pit duty this afternoon. But first the water tank needs refilling, and a couple of you can go see if the storm last night knocked down any decent trees for firewood.}}}
[[VOLUNTEER FOR WATER]] [[VOLUNTEER FOR WOOD]]

passages.name: VOLUNTEER FOR WATER
passages.text:
<<if $nofood>><<set $waterduty = false>>{{{It's cute that you thought I might let you choose after your pathetic failure last night.}}}

[[FIREWOOD DUTY IT IS|HE STRETCHES, POPPING MORE JOINTS AT ONCE THAN YOU HAVE IN YOUR WHOLE BODY]]<<else>><<set $waterduty = true>>{{{Normally I wouldn't let you choose, but after your success last night, I'm inclined to be generous.}}}

[[WATER TANK DUTY IT IS|HE STRETCHES, POPPING MORE JOINTS AT ONCE THAN YOU HAVE IN YOUR WHOLE BODY]]<<endif>>

destination.name: HE STRETCHES, POPPING MORE JOINTS AT ONCE THAN YOU HAVE IN YOUR WHOLE BODY
HE STRETCHES, POPPING MORE JOINTS AT ONCE THAN YOU HAVE IN YOUR WHOLE BODY

passages.name: VOLUNTEER FOR WOOD
passages.text:
<<if $nofood>><<set $waterduty = true>>{{{It's cute that you thought I might let you choose after your pathetic failure last night.}}}

[[WATER TANK DUTY IT IS|HE STRETCHES, POPPING MORE JOINTS AT ONCE THAN YOU HAVE IN YOUR WHOLE BODY]]<<else>><<set $waterduty = false>>{{{Normally I wouldn't let you choose, but after your success last night, I'm inclined to be generous.}}}

[[FIREWOOD DUTY IT IS|HE STRETCHES, POPPING MORE JOINTS AT ONCE THAN YOU HAVE IN YOUR WHOLE BODY]]<<endif>>

destination.name: HE STRETCHES, POPPING MORE JOINTS AT ONCE THAN YOU HAVE IN YOUR WHOLE BODY
HE STRETCHES, POPPING MORE JOINTS AT ONCE THAN YOU HAVE IN YOUR WHOLE BODY

passages.name: HE STRETCHES, POPPING MORE JOINTS AT ONCE THAN YOU HAVE IN YOUR WHOLE BODY
passages.text:
<<if $waterduty>>{{{You'd better take Grace with you. She's in no state to be anywhere near sharp edges. And Humphrey, too – maybe he can irritate the both of you into staying awake.}}}<<else>>{{{You'd better take Grace with you, and Humphrey too. Maybe he can irritate the both of you into staying awake.}}}<<endif>>

<<if $waterduty>>[[AND YOU'RE DISMISSED|water]]<<else>>[[AND YOU'RE DISMISSED|wood]]<<endif>>

passages.name: PAT HER HEAD
passages.text:
She doesn't look at you, but the visible portion of her face suggests a shy smile.

[[A SMALL VICTORY|dawn]]

passages.name: ASK ABOUT HIS CLOTHES
passages.text:
"This is just what I was wearing when he brought me here. Normally he takes kids when they're asleep, but... you know, it's kind of a long story."

[[YOU'RE COLD IN YOUR PYJAMAS|dawn]]

passages.name: water
passages.text:
Outside, the day is clear and crisp after last night's rain. Tabitha and Peter set off down the hillside with baskets, a rusty hand saw and a hatchet between them.

[[YOUR BREATH MISTS IN THE AIR]]

links.text: YOUR BREATH MISTS IN THE AIR

destination.name: YOUR BREATH MISTS IN THE AIR

passages.name: wood
passages.text:
Outside, the day is clear and crisp after last night's rain.

[[YOUR BREATH MISTS IN THE AIR|wood1]]

links.text: YOUR BREATH MISTS IN THE AIR

passages.name: release
passages.text: <><>The Bogeyman lifts you over the threshold by the scruff of your rain-soaked pyjamas. Well well. Look what the storm washed up. [[HE SHUTS THE DOOR AGAINST THE NIGHT]]

links.text: HE SHUTS THE DOOR AGAINST THE NIGHT

destination.name: HE SHUTS THE DOOR AGAINST THE NIGHT

passages.name: YOUR BREATH MISTS IN THE AIR
passages.text:
The Bogeyman doesn't seem bothered by the cold. Before she left he had Tabitha drag his chair into the kitchen doorway, blocking the entire frame, and now he's sitting there with his boots up on one of the smaller chairs.

[[HE TAKES A TIN OUT FROM SOMEWHERE INSIDE HIS ROBES]]

links.text: HE TAKES A TIN OUT FROM SOMEWHERE INSIDE HIS ROBES

destination.name: HE TAKES A TIN OUT FROM SOMEWHERE INSIDE HIS ROBES

passages.name: HE TAKES A TIN OUT FROM SOMEWHERE INSIDE HIS ROBES
passages.text:
{{{Only one way to warm up if you're cold,}}} he advises you, taking a pinch of something black out of the tin and putting it in his mouth. {{{Get to work!}}}

[[HE SETTLES BACK IN HIS CHAIR, CHEWING CONTENTEDLY]]

links.text: HE SETTLES BACK IN HIS CHAIR, CHEWING CONTENTEDLY

destination.name: HE SETTLES BACK IN HIS CHAIR, CHEWING CONTENTEDLY

passages.name: HE SETTLES BACK IN HIS CHAIR, CHEWING CONTENTEDLY
passages.text:
In the light of day, you get your first good look at the landscape. The hovel is built on a small plateau between two vast, barren expanses of steep. Above you in the distance the land tapers to an icy peak, while below – far beyond the copse – the base of the mountain is ringed by a much larger forest.

[[THE HORIZON IS BLOCKED BY FOUR IDENTICAL MOUNTAINS]]

links.text: THE HORIZON IS BLOCKED BY FOUR IDENTICAL MOUNTAINS

destination.name: THE HORIZON IS BLOCKED BY FOUR IDENTICAL MOUNTAINS

passages.name: THE HORIZON IS BLOCKED BY FOUR IDENTICAL MOUNTAINS
passages.text:
Closer to home, you see a woodshed and an outhouse, both of them even more ramshackle than the hovel itself. The surrounding earth is relatively clear of rocks, revealing a narrow pit not far away.

[[HUMPHREY LEADS YOU TO THE WOODSHED|watershed]]

links.text: HUMPHREY LEADS YOU TO THE WOODSHED

passages.name: watershed
passages.text:
He unlocks the door with a key entrusted to him by the Bogeyman, dips inside, and emerges moments later with three tin buckets.

[[HE HANDS ONE EACH TO YOU AND GRACE]]

links.text: HE HANDS ONE EACH TO YOU AND GRACE

destination.name: HE HANDS ONE EACH TO YOU AND GRACE

passages.name: wood1
passages.text:
The Bogeyman doesn't seem bothered by the cold. After breakfast he had the older children drag his chair into the kitchen doorway, blocking the entire frame, and now he's sitting there with his boots up on one of the smaller chairs.

[[HE TAKES A TIN OUT FROM SOMEWHERE INSIDE HIS ROBES|wood2]]

links.text: HE TAKES A TIN OUT FROM SOMEWHERE INSIDE HIS ROBES

passages.name: wood2
passages.text:
{{{Only one way to warm up if you're cold,}}} he advises you, taking a pinch of something black out of the tin and putting it in his mouth. {{{Get to work!}}}

[[HE SETTLES BACK IN HIS CHAIR, CHEWING CONTENTEDLY|wood3]]

links.text: HE SETTLES BACK IN HIS CHAIR, CHEWING CONTENTEDLY

passages.name: wood3
passages.text:
In the light of day, you get your first good look at the landscape. The hovel is built on a small plateau between two vast, barren expanses of steep. Above you in the distance the land tapers to an icy peak, while below – far beyond the copse – the base of the mountain is ringed by a much larger forest.

[[THE HORIZON IS BLOCKED BY FOUR IDENTICAL MOUNTAINS|wood4]]

links.text: THE HORIZON IS BLOCKED BY FOUR IDENTICAL MOUNTAINS

passages.name: wood4
passages.text:
Closer to home, you see a woodshed and an outhouse, both of them even more ramshackle than the hovel itself. The surrounding earth is relatively clear of rocks, revealing a narrow pit not far away.

[[HUMPHREY LEADS YOU TO THE WOODSHED]]

links.text: HUMPHREY LEADS YOU TO THE WOODSHED

destination.name: HUMPHREY LEADS YOU TO THE WOODSHED

passages.name: HUMPHREY LEADS YOU TO THE WOODSHED
passages.text:
He unlocks the door with a key entrusted to him by the Bogeyman, dips inside, and emerges moments later with three wicker baskets. Inside one of them sits a single hatchet and a rusty handsaw.

[[HE HANDS THE EMPTY BASKETS TO YOU AND GRACE]]

links.text: HE HANDS THE EMPTY BASKETS TO YOU AND GRACE

destination.name: HE HANDS THE EMPTY BASKETS TO YOU AND GRACE

passages.name: HE HANDS THE EMPTY BASKETS TO YOU AND GRACE
passages.text:
After re-locking the door, the three of you set off down the hillside. The rocks are easier to navigate by daylight, but it's still tough on your feet.

[[BE CAREFUL]]

passages.name: BE CAREFUL
passages.text:
It's a quiet walk. You can't tell whether Humphrey is sulking or always like this. Grace, on the other hand, is deep in a daze – not merely shy, but almost sleepwalking.
[[MAKE CONVERSATION]] [[WALK QUIETLY]]

passages.name: MAKE CONVERSATION
passages.text:
<>
[[WHAT'S PIT DUTY]] [[WHAT WAS IN THAT TIN]]
[[THIS IS FUN]] [[THIS IS STUPID]]

passages.name: WALK QUIETLY
passages.text:
The three of you trudge on towards the copse. As you draw closer, its crests loom above you, mapping a dark net across the blue sky.

[[HUMPHREY LEADS THE WAY INTO THE THICKET]]

links.text: HUMPHREY LEADS THE WAY INTO THE THICKET

destination.name: HUMPHREY LEADS THE WAY INTO THE THICKET

passages.name: HUMPHREY LEADS THE WAY INTO THE THICKET
passages.text:
Still-damp vegetation slaps against your arms and neck as you clamber your way between the trees. You can hear small things alive in the undergrowth.<> By the light of day, the copse seems far smaller than it did last night.<>
<>[[LOOK FOR THE NEST|trees]]<>[[INVESTIGATE THE TREES|trees]]<> <>[[LOOK FOR THE BURROW|ground]]<>[[INVESTIGATE THE GROUND|ground]]<>

passages.name: WHAT'S PIT DUTY
passages.text:
"Digging a pit," Humphrey explains, mock-patiently. "It's pretty straightforward, if you're not an idiot."
<>[[IGNORE HIM|walkwater]]<>[[IGNORE HIM|WALK QUIETLY]]<> [[SHOVE HIM]]

passages.name: WHAT WAS IN THAT TIN
passages.text:
"Dip. It's like chewing gum for grown-ups," Humphrey explains. "It just makes him spit a lot. Look forward to cleaning up a lot of yucky brown spit off the floor," he sneers, "and out of your hair, if you try to complain about it."

<<if $waterduty>>[[GROSS|walkwater]]<<else>>[[GROSS|WALK QUIETLY]]<<endif>>

passages.name: THIS IS FUN
passages.text:
Grace gives you a blank smile; you're not sure she heard you. Humphrey makes sure you see him rolling his eyes.
<>[[IGNORE HIM|walkwater]]<>[[IGNORE HIM|WALK QUIETLY]]<> [[SHOVE HIM]]

passages.name: THIS IS STUPID
passages.text:
"//You're// stupid," Humphrey snaps. "When you've been stuck here for stupid months, then tell me it's stupid, alright? Just shut up and do your stupid chores like the rest of us."
<>[[IGNORE HIM|walkwater]]<>[[IGNORE HIM|WALK QUIETLY]]<> [[SHOVE HIM]]

passages.name: SHOVE HIM
passages.text:
His <<if $waterduty>>bucket<<else>>basket<<endif>> flies out of his hands as he staggers sideways. He doesn't respond, only rights himself and scoops up the <<if $waterduty>>bucket<<else>>basket<<endif>> with a scowl.

<<if $waterduty>>[[GRACE BARELY SEEMS TO NOTICE|walkwater]]<<else>>[[GRACE BARELY SEEMS TO NOTICE|WALK QUIETLY]]<<endif>>

passages.name: ground
passages.text:
<<if $foundhole>>It doesn't take long for you to locate the hole again, but it's flooded with muddy water.<<else>>You squat down. The air is warmer down here. You don't find anything but muddy puddles and waterlogged twigs, too small to be useful.<<endif>>

[[LOOK UP AND NOTICE GRACE|grace]]

passages.name: trees
passages.text:
<<if $climb>>It doesn't take long for you to find the branch that supported your weight. Looking up, you see that the branch above it has snapped off near the trunk. There's no sign of any living thing there.

<<endif>>These are not the kind of trees you get conkers from, or plums or apples, or catkins or whirligigs, or maybe anything except fire.

[[LOOK BACK AND NOTICE GRACE|grace]]

passages.name: grace
passages.text:
She's fallen asleep on her feet again, with her face squished against the trunk of the nearest tree.

[[HUMPHREY TOSSES A STICK AT HER]]

links.text: HUMPHREY TOSSES A STICK AT HER

destination.name: HUMPHREY TOSSES A STICK AT HER

passages.name: HUMPHREY TOSSES A STICK AT HER
passages.text:
It bounces off her arm with no reaction. He grumbles. "Stupid. I know she's annoying and stupid when she cries, but he still shouldn't give her so much milk."
[[WHAT'S WRONG WITH MILK]] [[WHY WAS SHE CRYING]]

passages.name: WHY WAS SHE CRYING
passages.text:
"She doesn't like shouting. Doesn't matter if he's not shouting at her. Just hates being near him when he's angry."

[[HUMPHREY GOES OVER AND SHAKES GRACE AWAKE]]

links.text: HUMPHREY GOES OVER AND SHAKES GRACE AWAKE

destination.name: HUMPHREY GOES OVER AND SHAKES GRACE AWAKE

passages.name: WHAT'S WRONG WITH MILK
passages.text:
"Well, he //calls// it milk. But it tastes different to milk at home, and it sucks. Makes you really sleepy, so you can't stay up past bedtime even if you try."

[[HUMPHREY GOES OVER AND SHAKES GRACE AWAKE]]

links.text: HUMPHREY GOES OVER AND SHAKES GRACE AWAKE

destination.name: HUMPHREY GOES OVER AND SHAKES GRACE AWAKE

passages.name: HUMPHREY GOES OVER AND SHAKES GRACE AWAKE
passages.text:
"Come on," he orders as she stirs, "move around more. Stab yourself in the hand with a rock or something. Whatever it takes to stay focused."

[[SHE BRIGHTENS UP]]

passages.name: SHE BRIGHTENS UP
passages.text:
"Can we sing a song? He won't hear us from down here." She turns to you excitedly. "You're new. You have to teach us a new song!"
[[SING]] [[REFUSE]]

passages.name: SING
passages.text:
You sing the first nursery rhyme that comes into your head. Grace catches on quickly, following your lead, while the three of you search out fallen branches.

[[IT DOES LIFT THE MOOD A BIT]]

links.text: IT DOES LIFT THE MOOD A BIT

destination.name: IT DOES LIFT THE MOOD A BIT

passages.name: REFUSE
passages.text:
Grace pouts. She turns to Humphrey instead. "You pick a song, then," she pleads.

[[HE SIGHS]]

passages.name: IT DOES LIFT THE MOOD A BIT
passages.text:
//The first crow was crying for his ma
Crying for his ma
Crying for his ma
The first crow was crying for his ma//

[[ON A COLD AND FROSTY MORNING]]

links.text: ON A COLD AND FROSTY MORNING

destination.name: ON A COLD AND FROSTY MORNING

passages.name: ON A COLD AND FROSTY MORNING
passages.text:
Eventually, you find a thick branch that Humphrey deems suitable. You and he take it in turns to saw while the other helps Grace to hold it steady.

[[THE SAW CREAKS ALONG TO THE SONG]]

links.text: THE SAW CREAKS ALONG TO THE SONG

destination.name: THE SAW CREAKS ALONG TO THE SONG

passages.name: HE SIGHS
passages.text:
Perhaps realising that he brought this on himself, Humphrey starts singing a nursery rhyme. Beaming, Grace follows his lead, and the two of them keep going while you all search out fallen branches.

[[IT DOES LIFT THE MOOD A BIT]]

links.text: IT DOES LIFT THE MOOD A BIT

destination.name: IT DOES LIFT THE MOOD A BIT

passages.name: THE SAW CREAKS ALONG TO THE SONG
passages.text:
//The second crow couldn't fly at all
Couldn't fly at all
Couldn't fly at all
The second crow couldn't fly at all//

[[ON A COLD AND FROSTY MORNING|saw]]

links.text: ON A COLD AND FROSTY MORNING

passages.name: saw
passages.text:
The saw is short and blunt and the handle slips often in your frozen fingers. Your arms are stiff by the time you've managed to carve the branch into manageable chunks.

[[BUT YOU DON'T STOP TO REST|crow3]]

links.text: BUT YOU DON'T STOP TO REST

passages.name: HE HANDS ONE EACH TO YOU AND GRACE
passages.text:
After re-locking the door, the three of you set off, tracing a diagonal path upwards and away from the hovel. The rocks are easier to navigate by daylight, but it's still tough on your feet.

[[BE CAREFUL|carefulwater]]

passages.name: carefulwater
passages.text:
It's a quiet walk. You can't tell whether Humphrey is sulking or always like this. Grace, on the other hand, is deep in a daze – not merely shy, but almost sleepwalking.
[[MAKE CONVERSATION]] [[WALK QUIETLY|walkwater]]

passages.name: HUMPHREY LEADS YOU TO A DEPRESSION IN THE GROUND
passages.text:
"Snowmelt," he says, and points to a brook running weakly between the rocks.

[[WATER SPARKLES IN THE SUNLIGHT BEFORE STREAMING THROUGH A CRACK BACK INTO THE MOUNTAIN]]

links.text: WATER SPARKLES IN THE SUNLIGHT BEFORE STREAMING THROUGH A CRACK BACK INTO THE MOUNTAIN

destination.name: WATER SPARKLES IN THE SUNLIGHT BEFORE STREAMING THROUGH A CRACK BACK INTO THE MOUNTAIN

passages.name: walkwater
passages.text:
The three of you trudge on up the mountain. As you get higher, its peak looms larger above you, carving a dark slice out of the blue sky.

[[HUMPHREY LEADS YOU TO A DEPRESSION IN THE GROUND]]

links.text: HUMPHREY LEADS YOU TO A DEPRESSION IN THE GROUND

destination.name: HUMPHREY LEADS YOU TO A DEPRESSION IN THE GROUND

passages.name: COLLECT SOME IN YOUR BUCKET
passages.text:
The bucket hums as it slowly grows heavy with water.

[[LOOK UP AND NOTICE GRACE|watergrace]]

passages.name: COLLECT SOME IN YOUR HANDS
passages.text:
The water is cold on your fingers, as cold as if you'd dipped them in snow. It runs over your palms and splashes back down on the rocks.

[[LOOK UP AND NOTICE GRACE|watergrace]]

passages.name: WATER SPARKLES IN THE SUNLIGHT BEFORE STREAMING THROUGH A CRACK BACK INTO THE MOUNTAIN
passages.text:
"It merges with more streams underground, and comes back to the surface as much bigger river further down. But by then it won't be safe to touch, never mind drink."
[[COLLECT SOME IN YOUR BUCKET]] [[COLLECT SOME IN YOUR HANDS]]

passages.name: watergrace
passages.text:
She's fallen asleep with her face squished against a rock. Humphrey grumbles. "Stupid. I know she's annoying and stupid when she cries, but he still shouldn't give her so much milk."
[[WHAT'S WRONG WITH MILK|milkwater]] [[WHY WAS SHE CRYING|crywater]]

passages.name: milkwater
passages.text:
"Well, he //calls// it milk. But it tastes different to milk at home, and it sucks. Makes you really sleepy, so you can't stay up past bedtime even if you try."

[[HUMPHREY SPLASHES WATER IN GRACE'S FACE]]

links.text: HUMPHREY SPLASHES WATER IN GRACE'S FACE

destination.name: HUMPHREY SPLASHES WATER IN GRACE'S FACE

passages.name: crywater
passages.text:
"She doesn't like shouting. Doesn't matter if he's not shouting at her. Just hates being near him when he's angry."

[[HUMPHREY SPLASHES WATER IN GRACE'S FACE]]

links.text: HUMPHREY SPLASHES WATER IN GRACE'S FACE

destination.name: HUMPHREY SPLASHES WATER IN GRACE'S FACE

passages.name: HUMPHREY SPLASHES WATER IN GRACE'S FACE
passages.text:
"Come on," he orders as she stirs, "move around more. Stab yourself in the hand with a rock or something. Whatever it takes to stay focused."

[[SHE BRIGHTENS UP|watersong]]

passages.name: watersong
passages.text:
"Can we sing a song? He won't hear us from up here." She turns to you excitedly. "You're new. You have to teach us a new song!"
[[SING|watersing]] [[REFUSE|waterrefuse]]

passages.name: watersing
passages.text:
You sing the first nursery rhyme that comes into your head. Grace catches on quickly, following your lead, while you take it in turns to fill your buckets.

[[IT DOES LIFT THE MOOD A BIT|bitwater]]

links.text: IT DOES LIFT THE MOOD A BIT

passages.name: waterrefuse
passages.text:
Grace pouts. She turns to Humphrey instead. "You pick a song, then," she pleads.

[[HE SIGHS|watersigh]]

passages.name: bitwater
passages.text:
//The first crow was crying for his ma
Crying for his ma
Crying for his ma
The first crow was crying for his ma//

[[ON A COLD AND FROSTY MORNING|morningwater]]

links.text: ON A COLD AND FROSTY MORNING

passages.name: watersigh
passages.text:
Perhaps realising that he brought this on himself, Humphrey starts singing a nursery rhyme. Beaming, Grace follows his lead, and the two of them keep going while you take it in turns to fill your buckets.

[[IT DOES LIFT THE MOOD A BIT|bitwater]]

links.text: IT DOES LIFT THE MOOD A BIT

passages.name: morningwater
passages.text:
There's no other sound but the gentle drumming of water on tin. For a few minutes you forget where you are, forget that you're cold and sore and hungry.

[[SOON YOU'VE GOT ALL THE WATER YOU CAN CARRY]]

links.text: SOON YOU'VE GOT ALL THE WATER YOU CAN CARRY

destination.name: SOON YOU'VE GOT ALL THE WATER YOU CAN CARRY

passages.name: SOON YOU'VE GOT ALL THE WATER YOU CAN CARRY
passages.text:
//The second crow couldn't fly at all
Couldn't fly at all
Couldn't fly at all
The second crow couldn't fly at all//

[[ON A COLD AND FROSTY MORNING|buckets full]]

links.text: ON A COLD AND FROSTY MORNING

passages.name: buckets full
passages.text:
With your buckets full to the brim, the three of you set off back down the hill. For as long as you're out of earshot of the hovel, the song keeps on ringing out, saving you from the awkward silence.

[[DO YOUR BEST NOT TO SPILL ANY WATER]]

links.text: DO YOUR BEST NOT TO SPILL ANY WATER

destination.name: DO YOUR BEST NOT TO SPILL ANY WATER

passages.name: DO YOUR BEST NOT TO SPILL ANY WATER
passages.text:
//The third crow fell and broke his jaw
Fell and broke his jaw
Fell and broke his jaw
The third crow fell and broke his jaw//

[[ON A COLD AND FROSTY MORNING|timidwater]]

links.text: ON A COLD AND FROSTY MORNING

passages.name: timidwater
passages.text:
You all slow as you draw closer to the hovel. You make out the dark shape of the Bogeyman still filling the doorway, imagine you can already hear him chewing.

[[AND THE REEK OF THE PLACE RISES]]

links.text: AND THE REEK OF THE PLACE RISES

destination.name: AND THE REEK OF THE PLACE RISES

passages.name: AND THE REEK OF THE PLACE RISES
passages.text:
//The fourth crow wasn't there at all...//

[[GRACE BURSTS OUT LAUGHING]]

passages.name: GRACE BURSTS OUT LAUGHING
passages.text:
And then stops, just as abruptly.

[[YOU APPROACH THE HOVEL IN SILENCE]]

links.text: YOU APPROACH THE HOVEL IN SILENCE

destination.name: YOU APPROACH THE HOVEL IN SILENCE

passages.name: YOU APPROACH THE HOVEL IN SILENCE
passages.text:
The Bogeyman watches you from his chair as you empty your buckets into the tank. Your heart sinks – it's not even halfway full. You'll be carrying buckets back and forth all morning.

[[YOU CAN HEAR THE SPIT MOVING IN HIS MOUTH|spitwater]]

links.text: YOU CAN HEAR THE SPIT MOVING IN HIS MOUTH

passages.name: spitwater
passages.text: While you stand there trying to warm your fingers in your armpits, the Bogeyman stops chewing for a moment to fire a glob of black spit at the ground by his feet. [[THERE'S ALREADY A POOL OF IT CONGEALING IN THE DIRT]]

links.text: THERE'S ALREADY A POOL OF IT CONGEALING IN THE DIRT

destination.name: THERE'S ALREADY A POOL OF IT CONGEALING IN THE DIRT

passages.name: THERE'S ALREADY A POOL OF IT CONGEALING IN THE DIRT
passages.text:
Without another moment's pause, Humphrey sets off back towards the stream, swinging his empty bucket.

[[YOU AND GRACE FOLLOW CLOSE BEHIND]]

links.text: YOU AND GRACE FOLLOW CLOSE BEHIND

destination.name: YOU AND GRACE FOLLOW CLOSE BEHIND

passages.name: YOU AND GRACE FOLLOW CLOSE BEHIND
passages.text:
You make another trip, and then another, until your hands and feet and face have all gone quite numb. On each return you see the level of the tank rise, inch by bitter inch, while the Bogeyman watches you and chews.

[[THE SUN IS HIGH OVERHEAD WHEN IT HAPPENS]]

links.text: THE SUN IS HIGH OVERHEAD WHEN IT HAPPENS

destination.name: THE SUN IS HIGH OVERHEAD WHEN IT HAPPENS

passages.name: THE SUN IS HIGH OVERHEAD WHEN IT HAPPENS
passages.text:
You're about halfway back to the hovel, and you hear behind you the unmistakable noise of metal – and water – and flesh on stone.

[[YOU AND HUMPHREY BOTH TURN]]

passages.name: YOU AND HUMPHREY BOTH TURN
passages.text:
Grace has passed out again. Her big eyes are closed, her tiny palms bleeding, as the last of the water trickles from the bucket at her side.

[[A HUGE HOLE HAS APPEARED IN THE BOTTOM OF THE BUCKET]]

links.text: A HUGE HOLE HAS APPEARED IN THE BOTTOM OF THE BUCKET

destination.name: A HUGE HOLE HAS APPEARED IN THE BOTTOM OF THE BUCKET

passages.name: A HUGE HOLE HAS APPEARED IN THE BOTTOM OF THE BUCKET
passages.text:
Between you, you manage to rouse her and keep going without much time lost. She wipes the blood on her nightdress.

[[WHEN YOU GET BACK TO THE HOVEL THIS TIME, THE BOGEYMAN'S GAZE BURNS YOU]]

links.text: WHEN YOU GET BACK TO THE HOVEL THIS TIME, THE BOGEYMAN'S GAZE BURNS YOU

destination.name: WHEN YOU GET BACK TO THE HOVEL THIS TIME, THE BOGEYMAN'S GAZE BURNS YOU

passages.name: WHEN YOU GET BACK TO THE HOVEL THIS TIME, THE BOGEYMAN'S GAZE BURNS YOU
passages.text:
Once you and Humphrey have emptied your buckets, he beckons the three of you over. You stand in a line, Grace's hands folded politely behind her back, Humphrey's stuffed defiantly in his pockets.

[[THE PUDDLE OF SPIT IS HUGE NOW, AND THE SMELL STINGS YOUR EYES]]

links.text: THE PUDDLE OF SPIT IS HUGE NOW, AND THE SMELL STINGS YOUR EYES

destination.name: THE PUDDLE OF SPIT IS HUGE NOW, AND THE SMELL STINGS YOUR EYES

passages.name: THE PUDDLE OF SPIT IS HUGE NOW, AND THE SMELL STINGS YOUR EYES
passages.text:
{{{What happened here?}}} The Bogeyman gestures to the broken <>bucket<>basket<>. {{{Was one of you being careless?}}}
[[STAY SILENT]] [[TAKE THE BLAME]]

passages.name: STAY SILENT
passages.text:
<<set $takeblame = false>><<set $survivor = "Grace">>There's a long silence. The Bogeyman's fingers are curling around the arms of his chair, his mouth opening to say something else,

[[WHEN HUMPHREY SPEAKS UP]]

passages.name: TAKE THE BLAME
passages.text:
<<set $takeblame = true>><<set $survivor = "Humphrey">>"It was my fault, sir." You have to fight to force the words out. "The sun was in my eyes. I slipped and dropped the <<if $waterduty>>bucket<<else>>basket<<endif>> and it broke."

[[THE BOGEYMAN STARES AT YOU FOR A MOMENT]]

links.text: THE BOGEYMAN STARES AT YOU FOR A MOMENT

destination.name: THE BOGEYMAN STARES AT YOU FOR A MOMENT

passages.name: WHEN HUMPHREY SPEAKS UP
passages.text:
"It was my fault," Humphrey mutters. "The sun was in my eyes. I slipped and dropped the <<if $waterduty>>bucket<<else>>basket<<endif>> and it broke."

[[THE BOGEYMAN STARES AT HIM FOR A MOMENT]]

links.text: THE BOGEYMAN STARES AT HIM FOR A MOMENT

destination.name: THE BOGEYMAN STARES AT HIM FOR A MOMENT

passages.name: THE BOGEYMAN STARES AT HIM FOR A MOMENT
passages.text:
And then rises to his feet, and grabs Humphrey by the hair. {{{If you ever lie to me again,}}} he says, {{{I'll cut out your tongue and eat it.}}}

[[HE BACKHANDS HUMPHREY ACROSS THE FACE]]

links.text: HE BACKHANDS HUMPHREY ACROSS THE FACE

destination.name: HE BACKHANDS HUMPHREY ACROSS THE FACE

passages.name: HE BACKHANDS HUMPHREY ACROSS THE FACE
passages.text:
Humphrey stumbles back, four dark stripes already bruising on his cheek.

[[THE BOGEYMAN ROUNDS ON GRACE]]

passages.name: THE BOGEYMAN ROUNDS ON GRACE
passages.text: {{{As for you.}}} She flinches when he reaches for her, but he only wipes the first tear from her eye to taste it. Since you're too useless even to fetch <>water<>wood<>. Why don't you start by cleaning this – [[HE POINTS TO THE SPIT POOL]]

links.text: HE POINTS TO THE SPIT POOL

destination.name: HE POINTS TO THE SPIT POOL

passages.name: HE POINTS TO THE SPIT POOL
passages.text:
{{{And then bring me some lunch. The rest of you can eat when you've finished your chores. Understood?}}}

[[ALL THREE OF YOU NOD]]

passages.name: ALL THREE OF YOU NOD
passages.text:
You and Humphrey get back to work, slower now that it's just the two of you, even accounting for the quicker pace you keep without Grace struggling to keep up.

[[THE TIME PASSES IN SILENCE]]

passages.name: THE BOGEYMAN STARES AT YOU FOR A MOMENT
passages.text:
And then rises to his feet, and grabs you by the hair. {{{If you ever lie to me again,}}} he says, {{{I'll cut out your tongue and eat it.}}}

[[HE BACKHANDS YOU ACROSS THE FACE]]

links.text: HE BACKHANDS YOU ACROSS THE FACE

destination.name: HE BACKHANDS YOU ACROSS THE FACE

passages.name: HE BACKHANDS YOU ACROSS THE FACE
passages.text:
You stumble back in equal parts shock and pain, your cheek burning. It feels like it's going to bruise.

[[THE BOGEYMAN ROUNDS ON GRACE]]

passages.name: turnwood
passages.text:
Grace has passed out again. Her big eyes are closed, her tiny palms bleeding, as the logs roll out and away from the basket at her side.

[[THE HANDLE OF THE BASKET HAS SNAPPED OFF]]

links.text: THE HANDLE OF THE BASKET HAS SNAPPED OFF

destination.name: THE HANDLE OF THE BASKET HAS SNAPPED OFF

passages.name: crow3
passages.text:
//The third crow fell and broke his jaw
Fell and broke his jaw
Fell and broke his jaw
The third crow fell and broke his jaw//

[[ON A COLD AND FROSTY MORNING|crow3a]]

links.text: ON A COLD AND FROSTY MORNING

passages.name: crow3a
passages.text:
Now you take it in turns with the hatchet, splitting the slices of wood into smaller wedges. Between swings, Grace ducks in to collect the chopped wood and stack it in the baskets.

[[EVERY TIME YOU THINK FOR A SECOND THAT THE HATCHET IS GOING TO HIT HER SKULL]]

links.text: EVERY TIME YOU THINK FOR A SECOND THAT THE HATCHET IS GOING TO HIT HER SKULL

destination.name: EVERY TIME YOU THINK FOR A SECOND THAT THE HATCHET IS GOING TO HIT HER SKULL

passages.name: YOU SET OFF, TRUDGING IN TIME TO THE SONG
passages.text:
//The fourth crow wasn't there at all...//

[[GRACE BURSTS OUT LAUGHING|woodlaugh]]

passages.name: woodlaugh
passages.text:
And then stops, just as abruptly.

[[YOU APPROACH THE HOVEL IN SILENCE|woodsilence]]

links.text: YOU APPROACH THE HOVEL IN SILENCE

passages.name: woodsilence
passages.text:
Inside the woodshed, there's only room for Grace and Humphrey to stack the wood. The Bogeyman watches you from his chair, still chewing, while you wait outside with the baskets.

[[YOU CAN HEAR THE SPIT MOVING IN HIS MOUTH]]

links.text: YOU CAN HEAR THE SPIT MOVING IN HIS MOUTH

destination.name: YOU CAN HEAR THE SPIT MOVING IN HIS MOUTH
